messages.content: What is the purpose of ComfyUI-Catcat?

The purpose of ComfyUI-Catcat is to transform waiting times into a fun spectacle by injecting random cat GIFs into ComfyUI renderings, enhancing the user experience by providing a visual indicator of execution processes in a fun and engaging way.

ComfyUI-Catcat custom node dynamically displays a random cat GIF at the bottom left corner of the screen during queueing prompts within a ComfyUI application. It listens for execution start and end events, showing a cat GIF when execution begins and hiding it once execution ends.
To install ComfyUI-Catcat, go to the ComfyUI/custom_nodes directory in the terminal, clone the repository using `git clone https://github.com/jw782cn/ComfyUI-Catcat.git`, and then restart ComfyUI.
Can ComfyUI-Catcat be customized with more cat GIFs?

Yes, ComfyUI-Catcat can be customized with more cat GIFs. Users can add new GIF images to the `web/images` directory of their project and update the `gifFilenames` array in the `cat.js` file to include the relative path of the new GIF images.
Is there a way to drag and resize functionalities in ComfyUI-Catcat?
Yes, an update was released on 03/08, adding the ability to enable drag and resize functionalities in ComfyUI-Catcat.
What is the disclaimer provided in the ComfyUI-Catcat documentation?
The disclaimer states that the extension simply provides funs and does not guarantee their proper functioning.
Who is credited for the development of ComfyUI-Catcat?
The development of ComfyUI-Catcat is credited to [Hyacinth] and built by [Chenran (Actually GPT4)].
Can ComfyUI-Catcat be used to improve the user experience during rendering?

Yes, ComfyUI-Catcat is designed to enhance the user experience by providing a visual indicator of execution processes in a fun and engaging way, transforming waiting times into a fun spectacle by injecting random cat GIFs.
How can one select the GIF images for ComfyUI-Catcat?

To select GIF images for ComfyUI-Catcat, follow these steps: 1. Place your GIF images into the `web/images` directory of your project. Ensuring your images are appropriately sized and optimized for web use. 2. Open the `cat.js` file (or wherever your extension script is located). 3. Locate the `gifFilenames` array and add the relative path to your new GIF images within this array.
